fields.description:
*Assessment*

As part of doing further investigations regarding issue EUCA-7994, it was discovered that cloud admins cannot view Cloudwatch alarms of non-eucalyptus account users.  This is important to help with enforcing scriptable audit policies regarding Cloudwatch resources of non-eucalyptus account users.

*Signs*

The following non-eucalyptus account user has the following Cloudwatch alarms:

{code}
$ euwatch-describe-alarms --region account1-user01@
TestAddCapacity	INSUFFICIENT_DATA	arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:scalingPolicy:2d9fe100-1d42-4627-8249-6f83f34805db:autoScalingGroupName/TestScalingGroup:policyName/TestScaleoutPolicy	AWS/EC2	CPUUtilization	120	Average	2	GreaterThanOrEqualToThreshold	80.0
RemoveCapacity	INSUFFICIENT_DATA	arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:scalingPolicy:3dd5b095-023f-41be-a52e-1e6f537632a9:autoScalingGroupName/TestScalingGroup:policyName/TestScaleinPolicy	AWS/EC2	CPUUtilization	120	Average	2	LessThanOrEqualToThreshold	40.0
{code}

I attemped to view the CloudWatch alarms by using the admin user of the eucalyptus account, but it could not see the resource:

{code}
$ euwatch-describe-alarms verbose --region admin@
$
$ euwatch-describe-alarms --region admin@
$
{code}

*Steps*

* Set up a Eucalyptus 3.4.0 Cloud, with the following topology:
** 1 x CLC/Walrus
** 1 x CC/SC (Overlay)
** 1 x NC
* Followed the [instructions|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#user-guide/autoscaling_examples_intro.html] in the Eucalyptus 3.4.0 User Guide for creating a basic AutoScaling group and demand-based scaling policies. 
* Described the Cloudwatch alarms as the non-eucalyptus account user.
* Described the Cloudwatch alarms as the user under the eucalyptus account.

*Pertinent Data*

This behavior is inconsistent regarding other cloud resources that Cloud Admins can control that are associated with non-eucalyptus account users.

*Workaround*

Not at this time.
fields.summary: Cloudwatch Alarms Unable to be Viewed by Cloud Admin

comments.body: Uploaded sosreport from the CLC/Walrus machine.

Showing alarms across accounts is a tricky proposition.  Alarm names are only unique per account.  We don't have any way to distinguish who owns an alarm (which account) in the output from any of the describe-alarm* commands.

Change to address this issue:

{code}
git show 6807b2d5b04910b3c6487035880c1ca8254baf10
{code}

The change adds support for a "verbose" option when describing alarms and also supports passing an alarm ARN to the following actions:

* DeleteAlarms
* DisableAlarmActions
* DescribeAlarmHistory
* EnableAlarmActions
* SetAlarmState

IAM checks for these operations (and DescribeAlarms) now uses checking via RestrictedTypes.

Currently euca2ools output for describing alarms does not display the ARN, so I'll open a separate tools issue for that if we decide this change looks good.

[~sjones]
Review Comments:

Looks good overall, took me a while to figure out though that in AlarmManager.describeAlarms() and AlarmManager.describeAlarmHistory() the while loop queries until maxRecords is full, due to the restriction on permissions.  
A couple of other items
1) CloudWatchService.describeAlarmForMetric() was not modified in the same way that CloudWatchService.describeAlarms() was.  Does it need to be?
2) AlarmManager.java line 351: Iterables.any() is this supposed to have the iterables apply all the update predicate to all the alarmEntities?  (does it do that?)
3) AlarmManager.setAlarmState() queries: is there a way to streamline the query to just do one?  (looks like it looks just for name first then parses ARN if it exists)
4) permissions checks modified in CloudWatchService.describeAlarms(), .describeAlarmHistory(), .setAlarmState(), .deleteAlarms(), .enableAlarmActions(), .disableAlarmActions(), 
but nothing in .putMetricAlarm(), is this correct?

[~ethomas], responses numbered as per points in your comment.

1) The issue for DescribeAlarmsForMetric is with determining the desired account. Alarms have ARNs but metrics do not.

2) This is an error, I'll switch to CollectionUtils.each which I think I wrote last time I did this ....

3) No as an ARN is also a valid simple name.

4) This is intentional, we generally do not allow the administrator to create resources in other accounts (though update could be useful here). I think the other actions allow sufficient functionality to address this issue, we can always add functionality later if it is requested.

[~sjones] Change above looks good, one final question regarding original point 1) "describeAlarmsForMetric".  That operation returns a collection of alarms, as does describe alarms.  The fact it is related to a metric is almost of secondary importance, the metric name, etc, all that information is stored in the alarm table, it doesn't even have to reference an actual metric.  The reason describe alarms was changed was to add IAM support for restricted types, is this not also appropriate here?  DescribeAlarmsForMetric is simply describeAlarms with a very specific filter set.

The fix adds support for a "verbose" option when describing alarms:

{code}
# euwatch-describe-alarms verbose
{code}

for administrative use and also supports passing an alarm ARN to the following actions:

* DeleteAlarms
* DisableAlarmActions
* DescribeAlarmHistory
* EnableAlarmActions
* SetAlarmState

to allow the cloud administrator to perform these actions for alarms in other accounts.

Authorization checks for:

*  DescribeAlarmsForMetric

were also updated and should be regression tested.

TOOLS-397 has been opened to include the ARN for an alarm in the long output from euwatch-describe-alarms.

Fix Verified.

Cloud admin can list all alarms using verbose option and all stated actions can be executed by cloud admin for alarms in user accounts.

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 3.4.0
Release     : 0.0.221.20131111git304f3826.el6
